glossdef.simpara: Analog Display Services Interface. A data transmission format for analog phones equipped with an appropriate display which allows the switch to transmit calling line ID, number of messages in the voice mailbox, or programming instructions for the phone. Uses FSK ().

Asterisk Gateway Interface. Allows Asterisk to communicate with external scripts or programs (similar to CGI in web servers). The extended forms of AGI, such as EAGI, FastAGI and DeadAGI are described in more detail in .
Automatic Message Accounting. Describes a call detail recording () format originally used for direct distance dialling, or DDD ().
Application in the dialplan ().
Not to be confused with a dialplan function ().
Asterisk's built-in database, based on the Berkeley DB (BDB, )
In the context of a dialplan, see
An old but still widely used UNIX® database engine. Because it is used by so many applications it is rarely necessary to install it explicitly.
Sometimes abbreviated CID. Transmits the number of the calling party to the called party, and, depending on the circumstances, the calling party's directory name, for printing on a display.

glossdef.para: Call Detail Record or Call Data Record. Used primarily for billing purposes, the call detail record contains information about the time the call started, was answered, its duration, and time it ended. Asterisk uses the following format for its call detail records:acct code, src, dst, dst context, cid, chan, dst channel, last app, last app args, start time, answer time, end time, dur, billable secs, disposition, ama flags, unique id

glossdef.simpara: A channel describes a connection to an endpoint, which can refer to a user or device. Channels can use a variety of transport protocols, such as IAX (), SIP (), H.323, CAPI, ... which are described in further detail in .

An computing algorithm which codes and decodes a data stream, typically audio but also video. Examples of a codec include GSM, WAV or the well-known MP3 format. When referring to a codec, one usually includes the corresponding file format in the meaning.

glossdef.para: Describes a section in an Asterisk configuration file, primarily extensions.conf and voicemail.conf. Used to define specific behaviors for specific endpoints. For example, you may want phones in the sales department to behave one way and those in the shipping department to behave another, so you would assign them each their own context. Take care to distinguish between dialplan contexts and voicemail contexts. Voicemail-Contexten. See and .

glossdef.simpara: The call-handling instructions stored in extensions.conf, which are executed as soon as an extension () is dialled.

glossdef.para: Direct distance dialing. The trunking system, introduced in the 1960s, which allowed callers to make long distance calls (using a prefix, area code, and the number) without operator assistance.

glossdef.simpara: Domain Name System/Server/Service. A name server resolves names (e.g. example.com) to IP addresses.

Denial of Service. Describes a circumstance in which a network host is so overwhelmed with connections and connection attempts that it is unable to serve legitimate requests. Often, but not necessarily, malicious and intentional.

Differentiated Service CodePoint. A standardisation of ToS (type of service) flags () in RFC 2474. This uses the first 6 bits in the ToS byte of IPv4 (or, alternatively, the class field in IPv6) packets to prioritize traffic.
Because this prioritisation can be abused, most Internet service providers overwrite or ignore this bits (a trust boundary). You can ensure that your internal infrastructure honors them, however.

The most appropriate DSCP setting for VoIP applications is probably EF (Expedited Forwarding), which means reduced latency () and packet loss, and less jitter (). Alternatives include various classes of AF (Assured Forwarding), though these are not as suited for telephony. The default setting is BE (Best Effort), which implies the normal and lowest priority.

Dual-Tone Multi-Frequency. Known commercially as Touch-Tone®, these are the multi-frequency tones used by nearly all modern analog telephone sets. DTMF dialling replaced pulse dialling, which depended on precisely timed breaks in the loop circuit. In addition to the numbers 0-9, there are DTMF tones corresponding to the symbols * and # as well as the letters A-D, which are used rarely and only in special applications.

Distributed Universal Number Discovery. A peer-to-peer trunk routing system developed by Mark Spencer (Digium's founder) to enable gateways to find services on other systems. In contrast to ENUM (), DUNDi is decentralized and can be deployed within an organization or over the entire Internet. You can find more information at http://www.dundi.info/, http://www.dundi.com/, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DUNDi, doc/README.dundi (1.2) / doc/dundi.txt (1.4)

glossdef.para: This is the ITU-T standards track E.164, which defines the numbering plan for international calling. It defines the number and type of digits allowed in a telephone number for a device connected to the PSTN (), as well as the international dialling codes (also called country codes).

glossdef.simpara: Integrates an E.164 number and DNS (). An ENUM record consists of a reversed E.164 number and appended "e164.arpa"; the record contains the IP address of the endpoint that answers to that number. () einzusetzen. DUNDi () is a newer, decentralized way of achieving the same result. For more information about ENUM, see: doc/README.enum (1.2) / doc/enum.txt (1.4), RFC 3761

An extension, as it is used in Asterisk, refers to a sequence of symbols (usually numbers, but sometimes also symbols and letters - not normally diallable from a regular telephone but accessible from softphones) which represent either an endpoint or a procedure in the dialplan.

In addition, Asterisk supports a number of special, single-letter extensions which are not strictly diallable but are invoked in specific, pre-defined circumstances or through commands in the dialplan ().
glossdef.para:
These extensions are:
a
(Abort) called when the caller presses * during the voicemail ().
h
(Hangup) called when the channel is hung up.
i
(Invalid) called when the number dialled is not found or for invalid input in an IVR ().
o
(Operator) called when 0 is pressed in an IVR (), to connect to an operator process, device, or user.
s
(Start) incoming calls begin here.
t
(Timeout) called when the user fails to provide input within the pre-defined timeout interval..
T
(AbsoluteTimeout) called when the maximum allowed duration for the call has expired as set by Set(TIMEOUT(absolute)=timeout).
failed
Called when an automatic outgoing call with defined context, priority and extension has failed.
fax
Called when a fax call is detected on a Zap channel.
talk
Called when talk is detected by BackgroundDetect().
glossdef.simpara: In these descriptions we are referring both to individual extensions and patterns which may match multiple extensions ().

From the point of view of an administrator, extensions are a sequence of fixed commands in extensions.conf (see ) which are processed in order. In fact, an extension is just an entry point in the dialplan; to actually contact a device an extension must call a specific channel through the Dial() application. Extensions may also use patterns such as NXXNXXXXXX for matching outgoing calls.

Frequency Shift Keying. Used in fax and teletype communications, this form of data modulation distinguishes between character codes with a frequency shift, i.e. a switch between a lower and higher frequency, at a rate of thousands of times a second.
A function in the dialplan ().
Not to be confused with an application ().

Refers to the hook switch on a physical telephone set, which indicates to the central office switch that the receiver has been lifted so that it knows to provide dial tone and "off-hook" voltage. Increasingly virtual in nature with the advent of digital and VoIP telephone sets.
InterAsterisk eXchange protocol (Usually means IAX version 2, or IAX2; IAX version 1 is obsolete), an Asterisk-native channel protocol ().

Internet Protocol. A fundamental Internet transport protocol for IP datagrams or packets. Encapsulates the common transport-layer protocols TCP (Transmission Control Protocol, hence TCP/IP) and UDP (User Datagram Protocol), which again encapsulate the session-layer protocols such as HTTP or IAX. In contrast to a circuit-switched connection between two endpoints as used in traditional telephone systems, a "packet-switched" connection between two hosts offers no transmission guarantees.
IP packets are transported over a variety of physical media, including Ethernet.
Interactive Voice Response system. Lets you build complex menu systems with which the caller can interact, either using keypad input or through spoken word, or both.

Describes the variance in transmission time () of IP packets, which, if severe enough, can cause sound artifacts (such as clicks, pops, or dropouts) in VoIP () conversations. The impact of jitter depends in part on the codec () used. One way to compensate for jitter is to use a jitter buffer, in which a portion of the data stream is buffered, then checked and resequenced so that the receiving host does not perceive an interruption in the data stream or missing data.

Sometimes also called delay; refers to the time it takes for an IP packet () to go from the sender to the receiver. In analog telephone systems, latency is an issue only on very long connections; for digital connections (be they ATM as used by the telephone companies, or IP as used in VoIP), latency is a bigger problem because of the processing time necessary to convert from analog to digital and back, as well as route packets. Real-time applications like telephony demand low latency.

Media Access Control address. This is (usually) a hard-coded address fixed in the hardware of a network interface at the time of manufacture. In principle, every network device manufactured must have a unique address, so that traffic on the same physical or adjacent physical segments can be distinguished. Note that this is different from an IP address, which can be assigned arbitrarily -- the MAC address cannot normally be changed..

Music on Hold. (Note that, contrary to popular belief, you cannot use commercial music tracks as hold music unless you have arranged for use rights clearance. If you intend to use music from more than one artist, a variety of third-party companies provide music rights clearance services. Record yourself singing a drinking song to be on the safe side :)
The MySQL database (http://www.mysql.org/)

Network Time Protocol. A standardized protocol and algorithms to facilitate accurate timekeeping on Internet hosts. Lets a server or workstation synchronize its own system clock with that of a time server by polling the server for a time and calculating an offset based on the time it took the response to travel from the time server to the querying host. Time servers are organized into "strata"; a "stratum 1" server is usually connected to a reliable time source such as a radio or atomic clock.
In Asterisk, refers to another telephone system (PBX) to which Asterisk connects via a channel () usually over an IP network. May also be used to describe an Asterisk system at another location.

Private Branch eXchange. Name given to a small-scale switching exchange located on the premises of a business; basically another name for a telephone system. Connects devices (usually telephone sets) together and with the PSTN (see ).

glossdef.para: Pound sign = (#); in most countries this is called the "number sign", and this is the Unicode name for the character.

glossdef.simpara: Public Switched Telephone Network. The public telephone network we all know and love. Originally only an analog system; in the 1960s, began a slow conversion to digital. Today analog trunking technology is obsolete, and virtually all telephone communications are digital over at least some portion of their travel.

Quality of Service. Describes the total sum of all factors affecting call quality on a packet-switched connection, such as latency (), jitter (), throughput, error rate and packet loss. If supported by the hardware, traffic may be prioritized according to type of service () in order to maximize quality of service for voice traffic.
also called RegEx or RE. See

A syntax for describing textual patterns which should match a set of cases. In the case of an Asterisk dialplan () we refer to a dialling pattern which matches multiple extensions () and which is used to enhance readability and comprehensibility of the dialplan. Extension patterns always begin with _ (underscore). Placeholders such as number ranges [0-9], [3-6], [56] etc. or predefined short forms such as X (0-9), Z (1-9), N (2-9) und . (period -- all digits) are also allowed.
Example: _2[3-6]X
For a more comprehensive explanation, see and .

glossdef.para: Session Initiation Protocol (which is really a suite of protocols); in Asterisk, this is a channel type and driver ().

glossdef.simpara: Transmission Control Protocol. A transport-layer protocol in IP () which ensures that no packets are lost in a conversation. This is important for protocols such as HTTP, which depend on complete transmission of data.

Type of Service. A form of traffic classification used for prioritizing traffic in IP networks (). Some routers pay attention to the ToS flags in a packet to sort the packets; low priority packets are buffered while high priority packets are transmitted immediately. This is useful for preferential transmission of voice traffic over data traffic, as voice traffic is real-time and hence sensitive to delay. Collectively this is a form of managed Quality of Service (see ). The ToS can be set by Asterisk for some channels ().
The ToS flags were originally defined in RFC 791; as of RFC 2474 they have been incorporated into DSCP () for backwards compatibility.
The old flags were "low-delay", "throughput" and "reliability". The new flags are described in detail in the DSCP standard.

User Datagram Protocol. Like TCP, a session-layer protocol in IP () which provides only "best-effort" transmission; i.e. it transmits packets but does not check to verify if the packets were received intact at the destination. Because of its low overhead requirements (since packets do not have to be acknowledged or retransmitted) it is especially suited for real-time applications, such as telephony, audio- and video-streaming.
A voice recording taken automatically by an answering system, usually in a voice mailbox ().
A modern name for an answering machine :) In Asterisk, voice mailboxes are defined in voicemail.conf.
A sound recording, in Asterisk in the form of a digital file, used to prompt the caller for input in an IVR ().

Voice over IP. This is the transmission of real-time sound communications over a data network originally used only for computers. Contrast this to the PSTN (), which is the transmission of sound over a circuit-switched, originally analog (but now almost entirely digital itself) telephone network. Often a cost-effective way to communicate; offers a flexible platform for highly programmable and modular telephone systems and IVRs (). ITSPs (Internet Telephony Service Providers) such as Skype and Vonage are well-known in the residential market, but VoIP can also be applied internally in a business or only internally, with outside connections being provided by the PSTN.
